header.name: chaos/preprocessor/tuple/core.h
header.author: Paul Mensonides
header.overview: The header defines the core operations necessary to use a as a .

macro.abstract: The macro designates the name of the data structure.
macro.para: This macro expands to . In other words, the identifier is defined as itself.

macro.abstract: The macro is an identity macro used to compare type names.

usage.param: The tag used to distinguish between data structures.

macro.para: This macro is used by generic algorithms to compare the types of . It should be used for no other purpose.

macro.abstract: The macro expands to a nil .
macro.para: Note that a nil is an empty sequence of preprocessing tokens. In particular, when a is used a , nullary parentheses (e.g. ()) are considered to be a unary . (This differs from the -specific macros which treat () as a zero-element .)

macro.abstract: The macro appends an element to the head of a .

usage.param: The to which x is to be appended.
The element to be appended to the head of tuple.

macro.para: This macro expands to a containing the elements of tuple with x appended to the head.

macro.abstract: The macro is an identity macro used to encapsulate elements.

usage.param: The element of a to be encapsulated.

macro.para: This macro is used by generic algorithms to encapsulate elements before they are passed to user-defined macros. Elements in a cannot be variadic. Therefore, this macro is a simple identity macro.

macro.abstract: The macro extracts the first element from a .

usage.param: The whose first element is to be extracted.

macro.para: This macro expands to the first element contained in tuple.

macro.abstract: The macro removes the first element from a .

usage.param: The whose first element is to be removed.

macro.para: This macro expands to a containing all of the elements of tuple except the first.

macro.abstract: The macro is a predicate that tests whether a is non-nil.
macro.para: If tuple is non-nil, this macro expands to 1. Otherwise, it expands to 0.

macro.abstract: The macro is a predicate that tests whether a is nil.
macro.para: If tuple is nil, this macro expands to 1. Otherwise, it expands to 0.
